repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is explicitly tested for: https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/aea4e6b84b38223c540266f8c57093ee2039f284/tests/run/test_coroutines_pep492.pyx#L2400

It turns out some earlier versions of Python assume that
C-API classes without a dict or slot are pickleable by the class
name. Currently it's isn't pickleable because it the class name lookup
is failing but this change makes it more robust.

Taken out of #4376

comment_data.body: I'm not sure whether this should be in the version-check guards - there's no possibly no harm in just being explicit and forcing the non-pickleability for any version of Python.

Not sure either. You could argue both ways – that it's safer to implement it and let it fail, or that having an implementation at all would rather indicate that there is support although there isn't.

Given that we seem to need it together with type specs, and thus, will probably "always" have it available also in future Python versions, I guess removing the entire guard isn't wrong. You can comment it out for now (and add a comment why) to indicate that there is such a relation to Python versions.
I've done that. It looks like `object` provides a default implementation so I don't think that the presence of an implementation indicates anything really

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1501,13 +1501,34 @@ static PyObject *__Pyx_CoroutineAwait_no_new(PyTypeObject *type, PyObject *args,
 }
 #endif
 
+// In earlier versions of Python an object with no __dict__ and not __slots__ is assumed
+// to be pickleable by default. Coroutine-wrappers have significant state so shouldn't be.
+// Therefore provide a default implementation.
+// Something similar applies to heaptypes (i.e. with type_specs) with protocols 0 and 1
+// even in more recent versions.
+// We are applying this to all Python versions (hence the commented out version guard)
+// to make the behaviour explicit.
+// #if PY_VERSION_HEX < 0x03060000 || CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SPECS
+static PyObject *__Pyx_CoroutineAwait_reduce_ex(__pyx_CoroutineAwaitObject *self, PyObject *arg) {
+    CYTHON_UNUSED_VAR(arg);
+    PyErr_Format(PyExc_TypeError, "cannot pickle '%.200s' object",
+                         Py_TYPE(self)->tp_name);
+    return NULL;
+}
+// #endif
+
 static PyMethodDef __pyx_CoroutineAwait_methods[] = {
     {"send", (PyCFunction) __Pyx_CoroutineAwait_Send, METH_O,
      (char*) PyDoc_STR("send(arg) -> send 'arg' into coroutine,\nreturn next yielded value or raise StopIteration.")},
     {"throw", (PyCFunction) __Pyx_CoroutineAwait_Throw, METH_VARARGS,
      (char*) PyDoc_STR("throw(typ[,val[,tb]]) -> raise exception in coroutine,\nreturn next yielded value or raise StopIteration.")},
     {"close", (PyCFunction) __Pyx_CoroutineAwait_Close, METH_NOARGS,
      (char*) PyDoc_STR("close() -> raise GeneratorExit inside coroutine.")},
+// only needed with type-specs of version<3.6, but included in all versions for clarity

commit.message:
Make __Pyx_CoroutineAwaitType non-pickleable

This is explicitly tested for: https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/aea4e6b84b38223c540266f8c57093ee2039f284/tests/run/test_coroutines_pep492.pyx#L2400

It turns out some earlier versions of Python assume that
C-API classes without a dict or slot are pickleable by the class
name. Currently it's isn't pickleable because it the class name lookup
is failing but this change makes it more robust.

Comment out include-guards

And just make the unpickleability explicit

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Make __Pyx_CoroutineAwaitType non-pickleable
